title: Tuesday, 19th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

PM

PM

On average each office user exerts between 16-25 tonnes of pressure on their hands every day. 15% of all work ergonomic work place injuries are due to Carpal Tunnel Syndrome which accounts for a staggering 615,000 lost work days in the UK, which costs around £44.8 million pounds per year!

PM

PM

!

11:10 am

BE

Nearly 20% of free float on loan and shares at a one-year low, so everything is price sensitive.

11:10 am

11:11 am

So go on, FCA. Stop imploding for five minutes and get Ocado to say something. That's what you're there for.

Yeah, like Bryce said!

Yeah.

11:12 am
undefined
BE

China take then.

PM

Ed Bowsher, senior analyst Share Radio comments on the China GDP figures:
“Today’s Chinese economic growth figures weren’t all bad. The good news was that the service sector grew 8.1%. China needs a fast-growing services sector to compensate for an inevitable decline in spending on new fixed assets. If the service sector growth rate can pick up further in 2016, then China may avoid an economic disaster, but that’s a very big ‘if.’”

11:13 am
PM

That's from Teamspirit Public Relations | thumbs up

PM

Junk PR for Junk Quotes on Junk Stats

BE

So yes. No one believes the China numbers except when looking for a spurious reason to pin on this dead cat.

11:14 am
PM

Here's Lex

PM

China: on message

The end of the world is not yet upon us. On Tuesday, China announced December economic figures. Despite fears of a collapse, fourth-quarter GDP growth was just a smidge behind forecasts, at 6.8 per cent. More importantly for the shift in economic structure, December retail sales growth was above the full-year trend.

Such data — credibly on the slower side of policy-determined numbers — are unlikely to change the view of either the bulls or the bears. Bulls can say that the law of large numbers makes a slowdown inevitable. Bears might argue that the country’s mounting debt is more noteworthy than GDP growth.

Both sides are right. Yet the same could be said of the US, whose stock market has had a six-year rally based on cheap money, and confidence. Of all commodities, the latter is one of few in short supply when it comes to China. Where the US has honed hubris to a force for its good, China has not yet learnt how to inspire. Turn this around and markets will surely follow.

PM

And here's Danske

11:15 am
PM

Chinese data this morning were a touch weaker than expected but nothing that points to an overall hard landing.

PM

omg smile

PM

The data overall still paints a picture of stabilization. However there is still no sign of recovery in Q4. However, trade data last week pointed to a rebound in import growth suggesting that a moderate recovery is under way. We continue to look for a cut in the interest rate soon to support the economy. We also still expect a moderate recovery in coming quarters as we look for a) an end to depletion of inventories, b) improvement in construction driven by higher home sales this year and c) a rebound in export growth. The Chinese economy is expected to stay fragile, though.
· The data continues to show an ongoing significant rebalancing in the Chinese economy with severe challenges in the manufacturing sector whereas service is pulling more or less all growth. Service sector nominal growth was 11.9% versus nominal growth in industry and construction of only 0.2% y/y. The manufacturing sector is struggling with severe overcapacity in the “old” sectors in steel, cement and mining.

· While the economy is overall still in what could be called a soft landing, the state of manufacturing is close to what we would say is a hard landing. This is why what may be a soft landing for China is in many parts of the world being felt as a very hard landing. This is especially the case for commodity exporting countries like Brazil and Russia. Countries that export more to the service sector on the other hand will not feel the slowdown as hard.

11:16 am
PM

And all this is good for 110 points on the Footsie

PM

We are surrounded by mad people Bryce

PM

fore you know it, some government adviser is going to pop up and suggest using the blockchain to fix the NHS

11:18 am
BE

Meanwhile, here's UBS.

BE

Property adjustment continues to be a key headwind
Destocking pressure continues to weigh on property construction and investment.
Property new starts contracted more sharply in Q4 to 17.7%y/y while total construction
(ytd floor space under construction) slowed further from 3%y/y previously to 1.3%y/y.
Property investment declined at a faster pace of 3.2%y/y in Q4.
Consumption remains resilient but faces headwinds
Consumer expenditure picked up pace in Q4 according to household survey data,
which is also corroborated by a uptick in retail sales, which grew by 10.3% y/y in Q4 in
real terms. However, with growth of real household disposable income slowing and
expected negative impact on employment and wages from closing of excess capacities,
consumption will face headwinds in the coming year.
We maintain our 6.2% GDP growth forecast
We continue to see GDP growth grind lower as ongoing destocking in the property
sector and its knock on effect on industrial and mining activities overwhelm additional
policy support. We do not expect exports to offer much help as G3 recovery remains
weak and RMB exchange rate is unlikely to depreciate significantly. We expect USDCNY
to trade at 6.8 by end 2016.
Top concern is capital outflows getting out of control
We think the biggest risk to growth is deeper and more prolonged property destocking
and greater knock on effect on the rest of the economy. However, for financial
markets, uncontrollable capital outflows, not slower GDP growth, is the top concern.
We think the Chinese government will use tighter capital controls, FX reserves and RRR
cuts to manage the scale and consequences of capital outflows, but do expect the
market to be extremely sensitive to any sudden large outflows and/or glitches in
liquidity management in the coming year.

BE

11:20 am
BE

But there's also some interesting number mashing on the Saudi defence budget

BE

Which came out between Christmas and New Year, so was widely ignored

BE

Most people just took the headline figure and said "defence ringfenced, all good."

11:21 am
BE

A reminder that BAE gets a fifth of revenue from the Saudis.

PM

Is that still the case?

PM

Goodness

11:22 am
BE

Yeah, though Eurofighter's been written down quite a lot so it's not as hairy an order book as it was in the past.

BE

Anyway, Sandy Morris of Jefferies goes through the detail of the Saudi budget properly.

BE

On 28 December 2015, as is its normal practice, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Ministry of Finance issued a press release to “highlight the actual outcomes of Fiscal Year (FY) 1463/1437 (2015), the 1437/1438 (2016) budget, and the recent economic developments in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia”. We do not profess a deep understanding of the budget process, but can see that expenditure has typically materially exceeded the budget – by around US$14.4bn and US$30bn in 2014 and 2015, respectively. We can also see that the December 2015 press release analyses the budget in a more helpful manner if one is seeking insight into the allocation for Military and Security Services. We still feel, however, that we possess a limited understanding of how the budget process unfolds and how significant a future budget is in terms of predicting what will actually happen. Nonetheless, things do appear to have changed.

11:23 am
BE

A surplus, normally. Saudi Arabia incurred budget deficits in 2001 and 2002, and again in 2009 (around US$23bn). If we do simple arithmetic between 2006 and 2015, we arrive at a cumulative budget surplus of around SR 1,489bn (around US$402bn), of which SR 581bn arose in 2008. We venture this is the context in which the projected 2015 and 2016 budget deficits of US$99bn and US$88bn, respectively, should be viewed. The past budget surpluses would suggest that there are reserves that could support expenditure for at least a further two years beyond 2016. The snag is, we think, that past surpluses may already been used to fund some expenditure excluded from that reported in 2014 and 2015.

BE

Revenues the issue. In 2015, total revenue is estimated at SR 608bn (US$164bn), around 15% below budgeted revenue. The 2015 oil revenues are expected to reach SR 444.5bn (US$120bn), around 73% of total revenue and 23% below that for 2014. Non-oil revenue in 2015 rose from SR 126.8bn to SR 163.5bn, with the increases mainly occurring under “Investments” and “Other revenues”, neither of which we can shed much light on. In the event of a sustained low oil price, we can imagine that non-oil revenue might have to increase. We have seen Corporation Tax mooted as one possibility, but no firm proposals. In 2016, budgeted total revenue is SR 514bn. We think it probable – based on the accompanying commentary – that 2016 budgeted revenue is based on a pretty low oil price, but the price assumed is not stated, as usual.

BE

Military and Security Services spending. We have not been able to pin down a number for 2015, but venture it between SR 300bn and SR 310bn (around US$82bn). In 2013, actual Defence and Security expenditure was SR 251bn. In 2010, Defence and Security expenditure was SR 170bn. The 2016 budget proposes expenditure of SR 213bn (US$57.5bn), which appears to represent a large reduction on 2015, but a great deal will hinge on where the Budget Support Provision of SR 183bn ends up being deployed – assuming, of course, that it is all deployed.

A crude understanding. We believe the 2016 Budget acknowledges things have changed for the worse and that expenditure may have to fall. At the very least, there is more uncertainty, perhaps as to the timing of a further order for Typhoon aircraft. We note that in 2014, BAE’s sales to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Ministry of Defence and Aviation were £3,124m.

11:24 am
BE

Oh, and as for the Rolls-BAE theory .......

BE

11:25 am

PM

With Saudi, whatever the budget maths, I'd not that they are currently dropping quite a bit of BAe ordinance on places like Yemen.

BE

So anyway, here to top us out on the theme is that Credit Suisse downgrade.

11:26 am
BE

We downgrade BAE Systems to Underperform (from Neutral), with a
target price of 470p (vs 460p). Adopting an underperform rating on a
defence stock is not easy in the current stock market and geopolitical
environment, but BAE Systems is not our preferred one in this segment
(Thales, O/P, EUR80 TP is), in particular after its recent strong performance.

BE

US exposure and GBP weakening are supportive…: BAE Systems will
for instance benefit from its 36% exposure to the US budget (investment
accounts are up 16% in FY16 and are expected flat in FY17). The
weakening of the GBP is also boosting its US sales and profits translated
back into sterling (resulting in a 2.0-2.5% revision of our EPS for 2016E-
2020E as we moved our model from 1.54 to 1.45).

BE

…But Saudi hopes and recent outperformance are not: However, BAE
Systems has been outperforming by 15% its US peers since the budget deal
announcement in late October, despite benefitting less than them (all the
more so that the budget is expected to be flat for FY17). Moreover, we
believe that the UK-Saudi relationship and the Saudi financial tensions are
not supportive of any large order in the near future.

11:27 am
BE

■ Catalysts: Presidential Request for the FY17 US defence budget on 9
February, FY15 results on 18 February.
■ Valuation: Our revised valuation (with a weaker GBP/USD rate of 1.45 and
a reduced expectation of a large Saudi order) comes to 470p. The stock now
trades on an EV/EBIT multiple of 11.2x 2017E, at a 10% premium to its US
peers despite having a less favourable exposure to the US budget.

11:31 am
BE

(@FJP: where did you go? Grain Store?)

BE

In terms of news, there's none. Apart from a CS note on BHP.

BE

Keeps an outperform. But is't a measured piece with regards the divi.

11:32 am
BE

We think management will use the upcoming interim results to put a line in the sand and
reset the investment case. BHP in the view of the market seems to have been slower and
more reluctant to implement a tightening of its investment spending even if capex has
already been reduced significantly. Investors have often been left with the impression they
could have done more – however we note the $7bn capex guidance for FY17 (CSe
$6.5bn), this level was last seen a decade ago in FY07.
The Chairman's November AGM comments suggests BHP will not destroy the balance
sheet for the sake of the dividend, especially now capex and costs have been reduced
significantly and potentially do not have much more to cut.
BHP's policy of reviewing the dividend each six months (not just annually) also means the
issue can be addressed in February rather than at the full year results in August. A
dividend cut already seems priced in by the market (yield 12%) - suggesting any
shareholder backlash is likely to be limited, but nevertheless disappointing.
BHP last made a straightforward cut to the dividend in 1988 reducing it from 35c in 1987 to
34c in 1988, and afterward its dividend was rebased for the merger in 2000/2001 with
Billiton. Potentially one way to soften the blow for retail shareholders who want some cash
from their BHP investment would be the introduction of an Underwritten Dividend
Investment Plan (or Scrip Dividend Plan).
This would mean the company can still pay out cash dividends and attached imputation
tax credits to those who want it (they will be diluted) but the net cash impact for BHP will
be neutral as new shares are issued to cover the cash paid out. It may be seen as a
similarly cute method of "raising cheap equity" as the $6.5bn 6.75% hybrid bonds were
referred to in 2015.

PM

(Shinshin -- ooh, missed a trick there)

BE

BHP previously employed a DRP from 1984 to 1999, so is not unprecedented. Many of its
oil peers have used or recently introduced Scrip Dividend Plans (RDS, Total, BP). BP has
had it since 2010 after the Macondo incident and although we think Samarco is likely to be
much less economically damaging for BHP, the additional cash costs from Samarco (CS
$2.5bn) could be cited as a contributing factor for cutting the dividend and/or introducing a
Underwritten Dividend Reinvestment Plan.
On our spot cash-flow table below, even if BHP reduces its divided by 50% it will still be
FCF negative at current commodity prices. To achieve a neutral FCF result, BHP would
have to reduce its dividend to 40c/share (~70% cut) which interestingly would still equate
to a very acceptable 3.6% yield.

11:40 am
BE

So there's no recommendation attached to this:

BE

Despite capturing the lower base effect and anticipating further costs cuts, we forecast negative earnings in FY’17-18E before VED moves back into profit in FY’19E. VED trades on EV/EBITDA multiples of 8.7x/6.4x (attributable) for FY’17-18E and a base case P/NPV of 0.57x.

BE

Having habitually disappointed from an operational perspective for more the five years,
recording unit costs as high as $2.73/lb, management appears to have finally got a
handle on the issues at KCM. Production was up modestly at 91kt in H1'16, however,
unit costs fell 14% HoH and management guided to Sep'15 monthly unit costs of
$1.61/lb. We now forecast unit costs of ~$1.70/lb, which should leave the operation
broadly break-even despite our low copper price forecasts.

11:41 am
BE

As I say, no recommendation.... Though "lossmaking until 2019" doesn't sound awfully like a buy.

11:41 am
PM

Successful First Closing of
Rocket Internet Capital Partners Fund
 First closing of USD 420 million Rocket Internet Capital Partners Fund – an
early stage and growth fund with a USD 50 million commitment by Rocket
Internet SE
 Fund optimizes raising of capital for Rocket Internet’s portfolio companies
 Fund provides basis for faster funding of growth opportunities for Rocket
Internet businesses and boosting shareholder value

PM

Berlin, Germany, 19th January 2016 – Rocket Internet Capital Partners (the “Fund”) has
today successfully held its first closing, with total commitments of USD 420 million of which
Rocket Internet SE (“Rocket Internet” or “the Company”) contributed USD 50 million, making
it already the largest European Internet focused fund and one of the largest European early
stage and growth funds, managed by Rocket Internet Capital Partners Lux S.à r.l. Given
strong investor interest, further significant commitments are expected in the near-term.
The Fund offers two strategic advantages to Rocket Internet. It will invest in Rocket Internet
business opportunities, thereby streamlining and simplifying the funding process by reducing
significantly its reliance on co-investors in individual portfolio company funding rounds.
Secondly, Rocket Internet increases its economic exposure to its portfolio companies
through performance-based carried interest, therefore increasing Rocket shareholder value
without dilution to its shareholders or taking on increased risk.

PM

https://www.rocket...20Release%20vF.pdf

11:51 am
BE

Cazenove says ...........

BE

FY16 outlook is unsurprising as management highlights ‘tougher market conditions and high volatility in 2016’ and reiterating its outlook of ‘volume driven growth ahead of our markets, steady improvement in core operating margin and strong cash flow’. We continue to see the focus on margin delivery as key in FY16 as Unilever rolls out its zero based budgeting programme and benefits from lower input cost (GM up 120bps in H215). Unilever’s FY15 came in line of company compiled consensus with EPS of €1.82. Q415 top line came comfortably ahead at 4.9% LFL vs consensus 4.0% (and JPMe 3.6%) better across the board and with a beat on pricing to 2.9% while volumes were inline at 1.9%. LatAm was particularly strong at 12% in Q415 driven by 14.9% pricing. H215 Core Operating margin came in light at +10bps (vs +20bps consensus) due to the tough overheads comps -120bps, offsetting GM gains.

BE

Nothing much to add from the conference call notes.

11:52 am
BE

Jefferies picks out a few interesting points though, most notably in Latin America.

BE

Acceleration in EMs too, but 'hyperinflationary' pricing a factor. Pricing in LatAm
was a whopping 15% in Q4. This contributed c250bps of 290bps of Q4 pricing & about
half to total organic sales growth of 4.9%. LatAm pricing was also a factor in Q4 acceleration
in Refreshment, according to CEO Polman's usefully forensic analysis on the call. Hence the
bearish critique this morning that this has been a 'hyperinflationary' quarter for Unilever
(which has elected, unlike the likes of Diageo and P&G, not to adopt hyperinflationary
accounting, or hive off Venezuela). However, volumes in LatAm were down only 2.5% in
Q4. Implied Q4 price elasticity of 0.2 is a low number and an indication that competition
have followed, or perhaps even exceeded, Unilever's moves.

BE

To which it adds ........

11:52 am
BE

Neither, ultimately, at least for us. But 11% EPS growth at const. fx speaks
for itself. The 'problem' divisions of Home & Refreshment are accelerating, as
are EMs. Yes 'hyperinflationary' pricing was a big factor, but what is Unilever
supposed to do - run a charity?

BE

Well, indeed.

BE

11:53 am
BE

Positive direction of travel overall. Unilever is making good progress in difficult
markets, fuelled by innovation. There seems to be plenty of pricing power where needed,
perhaps partly because P&G is so quiescent and has even bigger transactional fx issues of its
own. There is welcome clarity on the operating model and portfolio priorities, and Pitkethly
is burnishing his reputation for clarity and transparency. What's not to like? Still slow Europe, the inter-related issue of Spreads performance and Group valuation, with Unilever trading at a big underlying premium to NESN on a multiple of cashflows.

PM

Going into the interims today we had expected to have to upgrade EPS forecasts for the full year given the strong Q1'16 update. However, a more subdued Q2'16 than expected means this does not look necessary and we therefore maintain our existing forecasts. The VIX spiked again in Dec & Jan implying a good start to H2'16. At this stage we see no requirement to adjust our expectations but highlight that our EPS forecasts are 7% below Bloomberg consensus in FY17 and 10% below in FY18. We think the market is too optimistic and reiterate our 709p TP and HOLD recommendation.

12:00 pm
BE

Barclays is positive.

BE

Cost inflation high in H1, but stabilising into H2: IG has released strong revenue
growth in H1 16 of 8.8%. PBT was -2.8% to £98.6m, with PBT margins falling sharply to
45.9%. At first glance, the profit decline is disappointing, but i) this is consistent with
the material cost increases already communicated at the FY15 results, and ii) the
outlook statement suggests cost inflation has now peaked. We believe the key quote
from new CEO Peter Hetherington is: “I am also acutely aware of the level of investment
our shareholders are supporting and our need to produce returns which match our
ambitions and their expectations. The rate of growth in investment spend is already
moderating”. Beyond FY16, the statement comments “the increase in operating costs is
likely to be much more inflationary and discretionary in nature, with any discretionary
element being primarily marketing related, and then only if the payback remains
compelling”. Although consistent with our forecasts (£25m opex growth in FY16,
dropping to £11m in FY17), recent results from IG have been characterised by ongoing
cost increases. Consequently, we believe these comments should be well received.

BE

No radical change to strategy, but evidence of sharpening up: The new CEO has not
made any major changes to IG’s expansion strategy. However, there is recognition of a
constant need to improve, whether these are existing strengths or weaknesses. For
example, the statement talks in detail about seeking to maximize the conversion of IG’s
flow into revenue, without taking undue risk. Conversely, the company has been candid
about its relative weakness in online marketing, saying “Historically, IG has not led
online, not targeted or tracked well enough”. The company now considers its online
marketing capabilities as among the best in the industry, with the approach becoming
more scientific. Finally, we note that SIPPs will be added to the stockbroking business in
H2, with IG reviewing its charging structure. The company comments it is intending to
become a cost leader in this market, which could leave IG as a potential disruptor.

12:01 pm
BE

Operational gearing is tantalisingly close, retain OW: Assuming improvements in
areas such as digital marketing and client conversion can be sustained to drive our
revenue forecasts, IG’s shareholders may finally reap the rewards of recent investments
as cost increases become more modest. With an FY16 dividend yield of 4% and cash on
the balance sheet, we see limited downside, but the potential for a re-rating starts to
build if PBT margins (already strong at 46%) can build from current levels. In the short
term, IG is also an obvious volatility beneficiary, as confirmed by the strong start to H2.

BE

Fair enough. IG always looks a decent business in a problematic sector.

Univision Communications Inc., the parent company to the nation's leading Spanish-language broadcast channel, has acquired a controlling stake in the satiric news site The Onion, NPR has learned.

The agreement between two seemingly disparate media outfits was described to NPR by a person with direct involvement in the negotiations. A second person who was briefed on the deal by Univision executives also confirmed its broad strokes. The amount of money involved in the deal was not disclosed.
